S’iba’aht hungers, and Olaf feeds it without hesitation.
Three heads seem to snarl in the mist—two of bear, one of berserker chief.
A mountain of rage and blood, Olaf leads his warband with feral fury and Khorne’s blessing.

Towering over his warband, Olaf Wolfhound is both warlord and beast. His frizzled mane of red hair and twin bear pelts lend him an unholy silhouette, like some three-headed god of battle. Fueled by a ceaseless fury, Olaf commands his Skaeling kin with brutal clarity and unwavering devotion to Khorne. Each raid, each slaughter, is a hymn in blood to his patron god—and few can match his zeal.
They breathe salt, chant Khorne’s name, and laugh as fire devours towns.
The longships of Viggslatra strike like lightning, and retreat only when the enemy is ash.

Handpicked by Olaf and baptized in the blood of his enemies, his warband fights with ruthless precision at his side.
Its cruel, serrated edge tears flesh more than it cuts, dragging enemies screaming to the ground.
Olaf bellows with the voice of man and bear, a thunderous cry that breaks courage like brittle bone.

Crude and cruel in design, Gorehook is more a butcher’s tool than a warrior’s weapon. Forged in the black smoke of a Skaeling war-forge and quenched in the blood of thralls, the axe’s jagged crescent edge is serrated and curved inward like a beast’s fang. It does not slice cleanly—it rips, mauls, and drags. Victims struck by Gorehook are often left writhing on the ground, hamstrung or bleeding out as Olaf steps over them to find his next target.
S’iba’aht feasts, its crimson hunger guiding it toward a worthy soul. The air screams, and the spear strikes like a god’s judgment—seeking blood, not mercy.

Forged in exile and consecrated in blood, this mantle is crafted from the pelts of nine dire bears—one for each brutal winter Olaf endured alone in the Howling North after defying and slaying his tribe’s old chieftain. Of the nine, three were slain with bare hands beneath a blood moon, their massive skulls now mounted upon Olaf’s shoulders as a fearsome trophy. Their snarling visages frame him in battle, giving the impression of a three-headed beast rising from a blizzard of gore. The cloak never freezes, never stiffens, and seems to repel fire and poison as if nature itself dares not offend its wearer. The Warhide is more than protection—it is proof that Olaf has already survived a fate harsher than death.
Taken from beasts hunted during Olaf’s exile in the Howling North, this cloak has never grown stiff with frost.

When fed the lifeblood of the slain, the spear glows with an inner, hellish light. But it is not merely a weapon—it is a prison. If left without slaughter, S’iba’aht grows quiet, its power waning until it slumbers again for centuries. When awakened, it speaks not with words but with yearning: visions, rage, and urges that twist even the strongest minds. It does not ask to be wielded. It chooses. The Three-Headed Beast has been muzzled—though the skulls he offered still grin.
Wreathed in bearskin and fury, Olaf bellows Khorne’s wrath and charges headlong into blood-soaked glory.

Across blood-slick shores and frostbitten stone, Olaf and Tuula chased whispers of the daemon-spear. Drawn by dreams and screams, they crossed the Sea of Claws, guided by S’iba’aht’s distant call. Each battle won fed the spear’s stirring hunger; each slain foe a step closer to the relic’s return.

In the howling dark of Norsca’s coasts, where the wind flays skin and gods demand blood, Olaf Wolfhound marches to war—not alone, but bound in sacred slaughter to his crimson-haired bride, Tuula Bloodhair. Their union is no simple love—it is a pact forged in fury, battle, and the worship of Khorne. Together, they chase the maddening whispers of a daemon-forged spear, long thought lost, its name buried in slaughtered tongues. S’iba’aht calls to them in dreams and rage, and neither Olaf nor Tuula will rest until its thirst is quenched in oceans of gore. Let the world tremble—for where Olaf goes, so too goes Tuula, and where they walk, war follows.

In the restless hours after battle, Olaf dreams of a spear bathed in blood-red mist. Tuula wakes from visions of black iron piercing the heart of a dying god. The images fade with the morning frost, dismissed as tricks of fatigue and battle-lust. Yet somewhere—beyond smoke and ruin—a greater power watches, weighing their worth. The raiding continues. For now.
Olaf’s mount crushes flesh and faith alike—pulping priests and princes beneath its wrath.
Blood seeps from its tusks even before battle. None know why. None ask.

The dreams no longer whisper—they roar. Olaf awakens with blood on his fists. Tuula's eyes burn with a fevered light. Crimson Rain howls from beyond the horizon, a siren cry of slaughter and promise. It is no longer a fleeting image—it is a command. The spear calls them to cross the Sea of Claws and tear through the lands of men to claim their destiny.

The spear whispers through crashing waves and burning foam. It is close—closer. Tuula sees it in the bloodied surf, Olaf hears it in the thunder of cannon-fire. The towns of Nordland tremble beneath black sails, their priests clutching relics, their temples hiding something… perhaps the thing. The sea brings truth, and Khorne demands the price for it. Every pyre, every skull, every desecrated shrine brings Crimson Rain closer to hand. If the Empire will not give it freely, then we shall take everything.
Salt and Ash, Blood and Bone

The gods grow louder. In her sleep, Tuula claws at the walls. Olaf has taken to muttering in his fury. The voice of the spear cries out through fire and fog, guiding their march ever southward—toward Middenheim, the Wolf-City. A priest dwells there, cloaked in lies and gold, guarding the truth of Crimson Rain. He will not speak willingly. Let his cathedral burn, let his screams echo through the mountain—let Sigmar’s stronghold become Khorne’s feast.
Crimon Rain: The Tithe of Flame

Crimson Rain is not merely found—it is earned. The spear is a relic of slaughter, a daemon that drinks not just blood, but the smoke of burning cities and the gold stolen from broken hands. It demands a tithe—a path of ruin paid in plunder and desecration. Villages must burn. Coffers must be cracked. Only then will the spear offer its next whisper. To follow the trail, you must leave one behind.
Crimon Rain: Salt and Ash, Blood and Bone

The trail leads to Nordland’s coast. The spear’s voice grows louder with each burning village. Its presence must be near. Sacking settlements may reveal those hiding knowledge—or guarding something greater
Crimon Rain: The Call of Crimson Rain

Tuula hears the spear in her dreams; Olaf feels it in his blood. The daemon-forged weapon known as Crimson Rain is no longer dormant. Its call echoes across the Sea of Claws. The trail begins—somewhere south, in the lands of men.
Crimon Rain: The Priest of Middenheim
A priest in Middenheim is said to know of the spear’s last location. The trail points to the Wolf-City, where faith and steel entwine. He will not speak freely—Middenheim must fall.
Crimon Rain: Only One May Bleed for It

The final piece falls into place. Crimson Rain lies hidden in a monastery at Dreizack. But another has heard the call: General Willi Ziege, an Empire champion. The Blood God demands a final trial. Only one may wield the spear.

Before the daemon within Crimson Rain will call out in full, Olaf must prove himself a true vessel of slaughter. Khorne does not grant his gifts to the untested. Only through victory and bloodshed will Olaf earn the spear’s attention.

The monastery lies in ruins. The spear, Crimson Rain, now rests in Olaf’s hands—dripping not with blood, but with raw, pulsing power. Within its blade, the daemon S’iba’aht stirs, no longer slumbering, but fully awake and aware. Khorne watches. A choice must be made. To bind the daemon is to master its power—Olaf remains in control, wielding the weapon as a brutal extension of his will. But to release it… is to unchain S’iba’aht's true form. A new warbringer shall rise in Olaf’s place. Flesh will melt, reality will twist—and the spear will walk.
Bind the Daemon: The spear is mine to wield.
Release the Daemon: Let S’iba’aht rise in blood and wrath.

At last, the dream sharpens into sight. Crimson Rain lies in Dreizack, sealed deep within a forgotten monastery built on holy fear and mortar-fed myths. But the spear does not whisper now—it screams. And not to Olaf alone. Willi Ziege, champion of the Empire, has heard the call. He marches not to defend—but to claim. To wield it. To cheat the Blood God of his rightful hound. There can be no sharing of this prize. No delay. The mountain must burn, and Ziege must die.
